Description: @agendapais2030 Esta semana se publicó un reporte de la organización internacional Oxfam -en conjunto al Instituto de Medio Ambiente de Estocolmo- que da cuenta de las emisiones de dióxido de carbono (CO2) relacionadas a los ingresos económicos a nivel global.  En él se muestra que el 10% más rico de la población mundial (630 millones de personas app.) generó el 52% de las emisiones de CO2 acumuladas entre los años 1990 y 2015; mientras que, el 50% más pobre (3100 millones de personas app.), produjo tan solo el 15%.  El aumento de las emisiones del primer grupo durante ese periodo, fue tres veces más grande que el del segundo.  Los investigadores afirmaron que esta desigualdad de las emisiones es parte importante de la crisis que estamos viviendo con el cambio climático. A pesar de que este año -debido a la pandemia de covid-19 y las restricciones que ha implicado- se han visto disminuidas las emisiones de CO2, esta reducción no tendrá ningún efecto si los Estados no toman medidas restrictivas a los principales causantes de estas altas cifras como el transporte aéreo y terrestre.  El Acuerdo de París adoptado a finales de 2015 en la Cop21, fijó ciertos parámetros urgentes para la lucha contra el cambio climático. Uno de los puntos centrales fue mantener el aumento de temperatura -calentamiento global- mucho menor a los 2°C durante este siglo, tratando de mantenerlo por debajo 1,5°C.  En el último tiempo, algunos expertos ya han mostrado su preocupación sobre la dificultad de mantenerse bajo estas cifras. Esto se confirma tras la publicación de Oxfam, en el que se ve que “entre 1990 y 2015, las emisiones anuales se incrementaron en un 60 %, y las emisiones acumuladas se duplicaron”. #emisionescarbono #cambioclimatico #medioambiente #chile 👉link en bio❗️
ImageText: Informe muestra que el 10% más rico de la población global genera más de la mitad de las emisiones de carbono por Sofía Roblero Valenzuela 23 septiembre, 2020

Description: China will be carbon neutral by 2060, President Xi Jinping has told the UN.⁠ ⁠ It's a new and ambitious target which could have a rippling effect around the globe. China has the largest annual carbon emissions of any country, and with the climate crisis so low on the agendas of leaders like Donald Trump and Jair Bolsonaro, the world has been looking to China for leadership ahead of a UN climate conference in Glasgow next year.⁠ ⁠ Speaking to the UN General Assembly in New York via videolink yesterday, President Xi also said that China's carbon emissions will peak before 2030. Experts pointed out that this is only a marginal change from a previous pledge, however.⁠ But the new long term 2060 goal is a "significant step forward", said Richard Black from the Energy and Climate Intelligence Unit.⁠ ⁠ “China isn’t just the world’s biggest emitter but the biggest energy financier and biggest market, so its decisions play a major role in shaping how the rest of the world progresses with its transition away from the fossil fuels that cause climate change," he said.⁠ ⁠ The devil, as ever, will be in the detail. China is still in the process of building rafts of new coal fired power plants, which are some of the most carbon-heavy forms of energy around. Yesterday's announcement will either mean an alteration to these plans, heavy investment in still-unproven technologies that remove carbon before it's emitted, or a rapid expansion of offsetting schemes such as tree planting.⁠ ⁠ The precise significance of yesterday's announcement will depend on these details. All eyes will now be on President Xi's next five-year plan for the period 2021-25, to be announced later this year, for signals on which path toward the new climate goals China takes.⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ #climate #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency #globalheating #globalwarming #carbon #co2 #emissions #pollution #report #netzero #carbonneutral #oil #gas #renewables #UN #diplomacy #newyork #china #nyc #fossilfuels #petrochemicals #investment #energy #industry
ImageText: China says it's planning to go carbon neutral by 2060 习近手 @channel4news

Description: 🔴 El casquete polar ártico registró este verano boreal (hemisferio norte) su segunda menor superficie desde que comenzaron los registros hace 42 años. Este año la superficie mínima se constató el 15 de septiembre, en 3,74 millones de km2, según el Centro Nacional de Nieve y Hielo de la universidad de Colorado Boulder. Pero... ¿qué es el casquete polar ártico? 🤔 Es la capa de hielo que se forma en el mar en esas altas latitudes y cada año, una parte se derrite en verano para volver a formarse en invierno. El problema actual surge porque debido al #calentamientoglobal, cada verano se derrite una porción mayor que no alcanza a recomponerse en el invierno, reduciendo cada vez más su superficie. Los satélites observan estas áreas con mucha precisión desde 1979, y la tendencia a la baja es clara. "Ha sido un año loco en el norte, con el hielo marino casi en el nivel más bajo de la historia, olas de calor (...) en Siberia y enormes incendios forestales", dijo Mark Serreze, director del NSIDC. "Nos enfilamos hacia un Océano Ártico sin hielo estacional", lamentó, remarcando que Groenlandia se está calentando dos veces más rápido que el resto del planeta.
ImageText: CALENTAMIENTO GLOBAL Casquete polar ártico está en su segundo nivel más bajo de últimos 42 años meganoticias.cl

Description: ⚠️🔴IMÁGENES SENSIBLES. Descubren por fin la causa de las misteriosas muertes de 330 elefantes en Botsuana.  Después de más de tres meses de revisión de los 330 casos mejor documentados, los responsables del departamento de Vida Salvaje y Parques Nacionales de este país africano han indicado que la muerte de paquidermos aparentemente sanos y sin señales de violencia está relacionada con al contaminación del agua que bebieron estos animales en el medio natural con cianobacterias (bacterias potencialmente tóxicas conocidas antiguamente como algas verdeazules porque los filamentos que forman tienen una apariencia similar a las algas -en realidad no son algas).  Por lo general, este tipo de bacterias no producen problemas graves a los animales, pero la cosa cambia cuando, por condiciones ambientales como el aumento de la temperatura (y el cambio climático es un multiplicador potencial) o la concentración de nutrientes, se producen floraciones repentinas o bloom de cianobacterias, con la aparición de toxinas que pueden afecta a diversos órganos. Una de las circunstancias más extrañas de este caso es que, aparentemente, los elefantes han sido los únicos grandes animales intoxicados. Ninguna otra especie silvestre se vio afectada por el agua tóxica en el área estudiada, cerca del famoso delta del Okavango en Botswana, indico Taolo.   📸 AFP/ Reuters Lee toda la información en el link de nuestra bio 📲 #elefantes #Botwsana #natural #fauna #africa  https://bit.ly/32OX4xU

Description: Are you Gen Z? Registered to vote?⁠⠀ ⁠⠀ Roughly 24 million members of Generation Z will have the opportunity to cast a ballot in November, according to the Pew Research Center. Gen Zers are those born after 1996 and combined with Millennials, ages 24 to 39, the two generations make up most of the U.S. population, according to a 2019 analysis by the Brookings Institution that showed nearly 51% of U.S. residents were under age 40.⁠⠀ ⁠⠀ Gen Z, the most racially and ethnically diverse generation, is also known for political engagement and activism not seen since the 1960s, and they're particularly concerned with climate change and its threat to the future.⁠⠀ ⁠⠀ Registering to vote is a quick and easy process. (And it’s #NationalVoterRegistrationDay, so there’s no reason not to!) Check your status at vote.usatoday.com, which you can get to in our link in bio. It takes less than two minutes. ⁠⠀ ⁠⠀ #Election2020 #donaldtrump #joebiden #vote #politics

Description: “Chile: el rechazo al Acuerdo de Escazú acaba con la aspiración de liderazgo ambiental” se titula un reportaje de Deutsche Welle que pone el foco en la resistencia del Gobierno de Sebastián Piñera a suscribir el Acuerdo de Escazú, el primer gran acuerdo ambiental en Latinoamérica y el Caribe. La nota del medio público alemán subraya que a cinco días de que finalice el plazo para firmar el tratado, Chile mantiene su negativa de rubricarlo. “La gran contradicción de todo este asunto es que Chile, bajo el primer mandato de Piñera (2010-2014), fue el principal impulsor y negociador para elaborar el Acuerdo de Escazú” junto a Costa Rica, señala el reportaje.  DW añade que los argumentos del Gobierno para no firmar el tratado internacional no convencen a los expertos consultados. “El Gobierno chileno parece darle prioridad al sector privado por sobre la protección medioambiental”, señala, recordando además que “el país suramericano está suscrito al Acuerdo de París y presidió la Conferencia de las Naciones Unidas sobre el Cambio Climático de 2019 (COP25) que se realizó en Madrid, evento en el que el liderazgo chileno en materia ambiental fue duramente criticado”.
ImageText: La mirada crítica desde Alemania al rechazo del Gobierno de Piñera a Escazú por El Mostrador 22 septiembre, 22septiembre,2020 2020 PRESIDENT Crédito: Reuters

Description: The Earth has a deadline. And the Climate Clock in New York City is keeping time.  Metronome’s digital clock in Union Square has been reprogrammed. Now, instead of measuring 24-hour cycles, it is measuring what two artists, Gan Golan and Andrew Boyd, present as a critical window for action to prevent the effects of global warming from becoming irreversible. According to the clock, there is a little more than 7 years.  “This is arguably the most important number in the world,” Boyd said. “And a monument is often how a society shows what’s important, what it elevates, what is at center stage.”  The artists’ goal of creating a large-scale clock was influenced in part by the Doomsday Clock, maintained online by the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, and by the National Debt Clock near Bryant Park in Manhattan. The artists said it was based on calculations by the Mercator Research Institute on Global Commons and Climate Change in Berlin.  Golan and Boyd decided that it would have the most impact if it were displayed in a conspicuous public space and presented like a statue or an artwork. It will be on display until Sept. 27, but the creators say their aim is to arrange for the clock to be permanently displayed, there or elsewhere.  Tap the link in our bio to read more about the Climate Clock. Photo by @jeenahmoon

Description: Calentamiento global, el responsable de la muerte de cientos de elefantes en Bostsuana.   De acuerdo con el Departamento de Vida Silvestre y Parques Nacionales, las elevadas temperaturas a nivel mundial causaron toxinas en el agua, producidas por cianobacterias, que provocaron la muerte de más de 300 cuadrípedos entre mayo y julio de 2020.  “Estas condiciones están coincidiendo cada vez más a menudo, por lo que estamos viendo más de estas proliferaciones tóxicas en todo el mundo“, dijo Patricia Glibert, profesora del Centro de Ciencia Medioambiental de la Universidad de Maryland.  Consulta toda la información en link en bio. . . . #calentamientoglobal #africa #botswana #elefantes🐘

Description: The mystery deaths of hundreds of elephants in Botswana has been solved. The alarm was raised when elephant carcasses were spotted in the country's Okavango Delta between May and June. Wildlife officials say toxins made by microscopic algae in water caused a total of 330 elephants to die. They ingested cyanobacteria - a toxic bacteria which can occur naturally in standing water and sometimes grow into large blooms known as blue-green algae. Scientists warn that climate change could be making these incidents - known as toxic blooms - more likely, because they favour warm water. Tap the link in our bio to read the full story.  Photo: EPA/Reuters  #Elephants #Botswana #Animals #Nature #Conservation #bbcnews
ImageText: (empty)

Description: La playa de Boulders Beach lo tiene todo. Sol, arena blanca, aguas cálidas de color turquesa... Esta podría ser parte de la descripción de cualquier playa paradisíaca, ideal para pasar un día tranquilo lejos de aglomeraciones. Pero si uno viaja hasta allí, lo que va a encontrar es una enorme colonia de pingüinos africanos.    Y es que desde que en 1983 una pareja se instalara en esta playa de Simon’s Town, un pueblo pesquero situado a unos 40 kilómetros de Ciudad del Cabo, procedente de la isla de Dyer, unos 60 kilómetros al sur, las aves se han reproducido, convirtiéndose en unos residentes de lujo. Se trata de pingüinos africanos, considerablemente más pequeños que otras especies más comunes -miden de media alrededor de 60 centímetros-, conocidos en el mundo anglosajón cono pingüinos Jackass (asno), por el tipo de “rebuzno” que emiten. Viven en las costas rocosas del extremo sur del continente -de Namibia a Sudáfrica- y se encuentran en peligro de extinción, amenazados por la contaminación y el cambio climático.   Boulders Beach se ha convertido en la actualidad en un excelente hábitat para estas aves. Incluida en el área protegida del parque nacional de Table Mountain, en ella conviven bañistas y pingüinos sin aparente conflicto.  📸 iStock  Lee el artículo completo en el link de nuestra bio 📲 https://bit.ly/32MxXMb #pingüinos #natural #viajes #fauna
ImageText: (empty)

Description: El 1 % más rico de la población mundial (63 millones de personas) es responsable de más del doble de las emisiones contaminantes a la atmósfera que la mitad más pobre del planeta (3.100 millones) entre 1990 y 2015, según un informe de la organización internacional Oxfam Intermón publicado este lunes.  Oxfam Intermon destaca en el informe 'Combatir la desigualdad de las emisiones de carbono' que los dos grupos más afectados por este desequilibrio son los menos responsables de la crisis climática, es decir, las personas más pobres y con mayor riesgo de exclusión y las generaciones futuras.  El documento se publica en vísperas de la reunión anual de la Asamblea General de Naciones Unidas para estudiar la situación global, incluida la emergencia climática, e insta a los gobernantes a aprovechar los planes de recuperación de la pandemia para adoptar medidas que favorezcan la reducción de emisiones y de las desigualdades socio económicas de la población mundial. Description: PLANETA 🏭 A Oxfam cobra 'justiça social e climática' nos pacotes de estímulo pós-pandemia, após seu relatório indicar que o 1% mais rico da população mundial emite o dobro de gases do efeito estufa que a metade mais pobre do planeta 🌍 A ONG avaliou um período de 25 anos, entre 1990 e 2015, em que as emissões de CO2 aumentaram quase 60%. 'Está claro que o modelo de crescimento econômico muito desigual e emissor de carbono dos últimos 20 a 30 anos não beneficiou a metade mais pobre da humanidade', afirmou Tim Gore. 'Os que mais sofrem esta injustiça são os menos responsáveis pela crise climática: os mais pobres e as gerações futuras', completou o especialista. Veja os detalhes do estudo no #linknabio  Foto: AFP
ImageText: No mundo, 1% mais rico emite o dobro de CO2 que a parte mais pobre da população ESTADÃO

Description: "We are facing a crisis, and one that has consequences for us all." That's how Sir David Attenborough opens his new film, Extinction: The Facts. Britain's favourite naturalist takes a very serious tone in the programme, which issues a stark warning about the damage humanity is doing to the natural world. It features some of the species in this artwork including the northern white rhino, which has been declared functionally extinct with only a single pair left in existence. They're protected 24-hours a day by armed guards in Kenya after poaching and civil wars had a devastating impact on numbers. The pink-headed Rapa fruit-dove and rusty patched bumble bee are also endangered, with numbers expected to continue to drop due to habitat loss and climate change. While the North Atlantic right whale is no longer hunted, it is critically endangered with an estimated 409 whales left. They're threatened by entanglements in fishing gear and ship strikes. Tap the link in our bio for more about the animals featured in the programme and details of David Attenborough's warning. Viewers in the UK can also watch Extinction: The Facts on BBC iPlayer. (Illustrations by Rohan Dahotre)  #Nature #Wildlife #Extinction #DavidAttenborough #ClimateChange #AnimalsOfInstagram #Illustration #BBCNews
ImageText: (empty)

Description: ¿Coincidencia? No lo creo 🙄 Cientos de pájaros fueron encontrados muertos en el estado de Nuevo México, Estados Unidos. La causa de muerte es todavía un misterio y el extraño comportamiento que mostraron antes de morir llamó la atención de los científicos. Lo cierto, es que el fenómeno es muy parecido a lo que sucede en #Dark, la exitosa serie alemana que mezcla sobrenaturalidad y viajes en el tiempo. En la serie los pájaros muertos tenían relación con algo verdaderamente tenebroso: un posible apocalipsis 🤯 Según lo que indicó al canal KOB la experta Martha Desmond "parece ser un número sin precedentes y muy grande". En la realidad, los especialistas creen que las causas tienen que ver con el cambio climático y una serie de incendios forestales pero continúan investigando. ¿Qué te parece? 🤔👀
ImageText: 2020 TAL COMO EN "DARK" Cientos de pájaros han caído muertos del cielo en EE.uน. EE meganoticias.cl

Description: La primera semana de septiembre, Francisca Castillo sembró un ensayo de trigo en la Estación Experimental Agropecuaria Austral, UACh-Valdivia, con distintos niveles de termotolerancia en campo.  Ella es investigadora postdoctoral del Instituto Milenio de Biología Integrativa iBio en el Laboratorio de Nutrición y Genómica de Plantas, donde se ha planteado el desafío de avanzar en el conocimiento sobre el cultivo de trigo, específicamente sobre los mecanismos que permiten a los cultivos soportar las alzas de temperatura en un contexto de cambio climático. Esto, considerando que los eventos extremos, como las olas de calor, son cada vez más frecuentes y constituyen una seria amenaza a la productividad de cultivos a nivel global.  La bioquímica y doctora en Ciencias Agrarias recuerda que el trigo es uno de los cereales más consumido en el mundo. “Provee alrededor de un 20% de las calorías diarias, y por cada 1°C de aumento por encima de las temperaturas óptimas en etapas clave del desarrollo del cultivo, se generan pérdidas de un 5-6% en la productividad de trigo, por esto su investigación resulta clave para la seguridad alimentaria global”, comentó.  Por eso sembró 14 líneas de trigo que provienen del Centro Internacional de Mejoramiento de Maíz y Trigo (CIMMYT). Estas se caracterizan por presentar distintos niveles de termotolerancia en campo, que es la capacidad de un cultivo de mantener su productividad en condiciones de estrés por altas temperaturas.  En este experimento preliminar se evaluará la expresión basal de algunos genes candidatos involucrados en procesos de termotolerancia, y se medirá el rendimiento de cosecha que se realizará a fines de enero 2021. En un próximo ensayo, explica Castillo, se llevarán a cabo tratamientos de choque térmico para evaluar la respuesta fisiológica / molecular de estas líneas de trigo en nuestro ambiente, lo que permitirá complementar los resultados del proyecto. 👉continúa leyendo en el link de la bio❗️
ImageText: Estudian termotolerancia del trigo para mejorar los cultivos en un contexto de aumento de temperatura a consecuencia del cambio climático por Agenda País 20 septiembre, 2020

Description: Patagonia  is getting lots of attention for a cheeky, hidden message that appears only on the tag of a limited-edition pair of shorts, in tiny print. But the label was only the latest Trump-era call to action from Patagonia. The company has responded to the federal government’s environmental rollbacks with increasingly vocal campaigns to protect the country’s public lands — and yes, it says the four-word message applies to the president, along with other politicians who refuse to act on climate change. Patagonia is also making “recommendations” for 22 of the 35 Senate seats up for grabs in November based on the candidates’ stances on climate change, public lands and environmental justice.  Read more about Patagonia's history of climate and political activism via our link in bio.  ✍️: @sammy_roth   #patagonia #outdoors
ImageText: The story behind that Patagonia tag, and how the Trump era changed outdoor recreation VOTE THE ASSHOLES OUT

Description: @revistageneracionm Según la Encuesta Nacional del Medio Ambiente de 2018, un millón y medio de chilenos llevaban hasta ese entonces una dieta vegetariana. Hoy, en medio de las celebraciones de Fiestas Patrias son muchos más quienes buscan opciones de origen vegetal para pasar las celebraciones de una forma mucho más saludable y empática con los animales.  Y es que ayudar a los animales, reducir el impacto en el medio ambiente y para mejorar su estado de salud, son las principales razones por la que las personas deciden ser veganas. Según datos entregados por la organización Vegetarianos Hoy, el 73% de los participantes en campañas de alimentación en base a plantas son menores de 30 años.  Hace 10 años el veganismo ya estaba presente en Chile, pero no ocupaba espacio ni en los medios ni en los muebles de los supermercados. Hoy la realidad es distinta, existiendo varias organizaciones que promueven este estilo de vida y una gran diversidad de productos disponibles debido al alza de la demanda.  Los jóvenes, entendidos como personas de 15 a 25 años, son el principal grupo etario que ha optado por el veganismo. En los últimos dos años esto ha aumentado, surgiendo diversas campañas en torno a la alimentación en base a plantas.  La campaña Semana Mundial Sin Lácteos fue creada por Vegetarianos Hoy para acercar a las personas a una alimentación basada en plantas, instándolos a conocer la diversidad de productos que sustituyen a los lácteos tradicionales. Esta se llevó a cabo en diferentes países, tanto el 2019 como el 2020, siendo Chile el que cuenta con una mayor cantidad de inscritos.  Este año la campaña contó con 3.314 inscritos, de los cuales el 73% son menores de 30 años. “Los jóvenes actuales tienden a ser más conscientes con los animales y el medio ambiente. Tienen mayor acceso a la información sobre cómo la industria alimenticia es uno de los principales causantes del cambio climático, extinción de especies y por supuesto el sufrimiento de millones de animales”, comentó Camila Ahumada, coordinadora de campañas Vegetarianos Hoy. @vegetarianos_hoy #vegano #vegetariano 👉continúa leyendo en el link de la página ❗️
ImageText: Conciencia M Menores de 30 anos son los principales adherentes del veganismo en Chile por Giannina Giordano 19 septiembre, 2020

Description: These pictures show the damage caused by the deadly wildfires which have been burning their way through the US West Coast over the last month. More than 30 people have been killed and tens of thousands have been forced from their homes. Lightning strikes in August sparked a number of the blazes, while warm temperatures and dry conditions have fuelled others. Scientists say the region's wildfires are the worst in 18 years and have linked their increasing prevalence and intensity to climate change. However, US President Donald Trump has blamed poor forest management for the blazes. Tap the link in our bio for a visual guide to what's happening - a month on from a state of emergency being declared in California. (📸Maxar Technologies, Getty Images) #Fires #Wildfires #Oregon #US #ClimateChange #Environment #bbcnews
ImageText: (empty)

Description: Los gigantescos incendios forestales de los últimos meses en California, Oregón, Nevada y otros estados de la costa oeste de Norteamérica están liberando a la atmósfera cantidades sin precedentes de dióxido de carbono (gas asociado al cambio climático) y contaminación por partículas en suspensión (con efectos directos sobre la salud humana).  La gruesa capa de humo de los incendios ha cruzado Estados Unidos de costa a costa, tiñendo de gris los cielos de Nueva York, y la agencia pronostica que llegará al norte de Europa a fines de esta semana.  Los fuegos, que comenzaron a mediados de agosto y continúan activos, han consumido más de 5 millones de acres (unos 2,02 millones de hectáreas) en toda la costa oeste, dejando decenas de víctimas fatales, destruyendo viviendas y empeorando la calidad del aire. Una plaga de escarabajos que ha devastado más de 150 millones de árboles solo en California ha dejado enormes cantidades de yesca, que alimenta las llamas. Eso, junto con las condiciones cálidas y secas, está provocando una de las peores temporadas de incendios en la región.  📸 Reuters
ImageText: (empty)

Description: Greenpeace’s Arctic Sunrise ship is seen navigating through floating ice in the Arctic Ocean.  Drone footage taken by the team aboard the ship shows the vast ice floes of the Arctic Circle.  Climate change has been driving up Arctic temperatures and shrinking the once-solid sea ice cover.  Scientists say the ancient ice sheet sitting atop Greenland shed approximately a 113 square kilometre chunk of ice last month.  They are also warning that the dwindling ice cover means an uncertain future for animals like seals and polar bears.  The Greenpeace ship is in the Arctic to witness and document the sea ice minimum – which is when the ice reaches its smallest extent at the end of the summer melting season.  #climatechange #globalwarming #arctic #arcticcircle #ice #greenpeace
ImageText: (empty)

Description: “Despite our modern 2020 world, with an app for everything, there is no app for digging fire lines,” said Holly Krake, a @u.s.forestservice spokeswoman working on the Riverside Fire in Oregon.  The basic techniques for fighting wildfires have changed little in decades. Along with using helicopters and tanker aircraft to drop the water and flame retardant, there is arduous labor on the ground. Some of it requires carefully burning areas in the path of an advancing fire to try to rob it of the fuel it needs to keep progressing. It can also involve dousing flames with water brought in by truck — or, in rough country, hiked in along with hoses and pumps.  At the most fundamental, though, it means workers using hand tools to dig the fire lines — the borders, cleared of trees and shrub, that can stop a fire from advancing by removing all vegetation and scraping down to the “mineral soil,” the bare dirt.  Many of the people who take on this backbreaking task are seasonal workers, and some are prison inmates. Their tool kits include low-tech implements of destruction, some of which are familiar, like chain saws and shovels. Others are odd yet exquisitely shaped to their purpose, like the Pulaski, which has a head with an ax at one side and an adz on the other that can break up packed dirt.  But today’s expanded fire seasons and raging wildfires brought on by climate change could render current firefighting approaches obsolete.  Tap the link in our bio to read how wildfires are fought. Photos by @maxwhittaker, @ericthayer, @chrismatography and @punkeykid

Description: More than a week after wildfires began blazing in Oregon, Washington and California, false and exaggerated claims about the fires’ origins are still rampant.  The latest, most viral rumor involves Domingo Lopez Jr., a 45-year-old man who was arrested in Portland, Ore., on suspicion of starting a series of small fires. During one of these arrests, the police photographed a bottle with a wick attached, a Molotov cocktail they said Lopez had used to start one of the fires.  But these fires were unrelated to the larger blazes. Local news reports noted at the time that all of the fires Lopez was suspected of setting had been quickly extinguished, and that no people or buildings were harmed. They also noted that Lopez was taken for a mental health examination after his arrests.  Law enforcement agencies, including the FBI, have dispelled the rumor that arsonists or antifa sympathizers are responsible for the wildfires, and scientists say that climate change is the primary factor behind the blazes.  We’re tracking viral misinformation ahead of the 2020 election. Times reporters will chronicle and debunk false and misleading information that is going viral online. Tap the link in our bio to read tech columnist @kevinroose’s reporting that extinguishes the latest rumor. Photo by @iancbates
ImageText: No, a Molotov Cocktail Didn't Start the West's Wildfires

Description: The number of acres burned in this year's California wildfires is the highest on record, according to the state fire department.⁠ ⁠ Figures from Cal Fire show almost 3.4 million acres have been scorched in this year's devastating blazes - around 12 times the area burned last year. The state fire department says 25 people have died since mid-August and thousands of buildings have been destroyed, with dozens of major fires still burning across the state. ⁠ ⁠ Elsewhere on the US West Coast, 1.6 million acres of land have been burned across Oregon and Washington state since 7th September, destroying several small towns and claiming at least 34 lives.⁠ ⁠ Scientists say climate change has extended the wildfire season and made the blazes more intense, as higher temperatures have left vegetation drier for longer.⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ #wildfires #california #oregon #washington #globalwarming #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateeemergency

Description: Fuego para abrir campos de cultivo de soja y pastos en los bosques brasileños. La ONG Rainforest Foundation Norway ha recorrido la sabana tropical de El Cerrado para documentar la destrucción asociada a la producción masiva de soja en unas imágenes que ofrece elDiario.es y que forman parte de una campaña internacional en la que participa Ecologistas en Acción España. ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀ El año pasado, los incendios carbonizaron unos 6.000 km2 de Amazonía brasileña, un 80% más que el curso anterior. El propio Gobierno brasileño admitió que el 80% de las áreas deforestadas del país se dedican a la ganadería. Meses después, la organización Igualdad Animal registraba cómo una gran hilera de camiones llenos de soja transitaba por la zona calcinada del Pará rumbo a los muelles de carga. ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀ "El principal motivo de la destrucción, la violencia y los conflictos es la expansión de la soja. El productor de soja busca constantemente más tierra para expandirse porque tiene garantizados compradores en el mercado", cuenta Valeria Pereira Santos de la Comisión Pastoral de la Tierra. ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀ El audiovisual que ha producido Rainforest Norway incide en la problemática que arrastra el monocultivo de soja: "No solo agrava la crisis climática y destruye la biodiversidad, sino que también afecta a las comunidades campesinas e indígenas violando sus derechos humanos. La expansión de la frontera sojera ha implicado el desplazamiento y hostigamiento", analiza Ecologistas en Acción socio de Rainforest Foundation Norway para esta campaña. ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀ Puedes ver más vídeos en el link de la bio. ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀ ¿Conocías esta situación? ⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀⠀ #Brasil #Soja #Deforestación #Medioambiente
ImageText: Reportaje Sangre, fuego y extorsión: el negocio de la soja en el Amazonas brasileño

Description: Opinion contributor Dr. Thomas Ken Law writes: "Coupled with climate change, heat waves and forest overgrowth, the lightning storms were the catalyst to the worst wildfire season the West Coast has seen in decades. Lives and property have been lost directly to the out-of-control fires; here in the Bay Area, the resulting smoke and ash has blanketed everything. Walking outside is like stepping into a crowded cigarette-smoke filled bar where they are barbecuing and have coincidentally also just launched fireworks. There are days where every breath leaves an ashy taste in the mouth and eyes watering."⁠ ⁠ Tap our link in bio to read more. ⁠ ⁠ ----------------------------------------------------⁠ ⁠ Dr. Thomas Ken Lew is an assistant clinical professor of medicine at the Stanford University School of Medicine and an attending physician of Hospital Medicine at Stanford Health Care — ValleyCare.

Description: Millions of people in the U.S. will be displaced by climate change. Where will they go?  Of all the devastating consequences of a warming planet — changing landscapes, pandemics, mass extinctions — the potential movement of hundreds of millions of climate refugees stands to be among the most important.  This summer has seen more fires, more heat, more storms, all of it making life increasingly untenable in larger areas of the nation. Already, droughts regularly threaten food crops across the West, while destructive floods inundate towns and fields from the Dakotas to Maryland, collapsing dams in Michigan and raising the shorelines of the Great Lakes. Rising seas and increasingly violent hurricanes are making thousands of miles of shoreline along the coasts nearly uninhabitable.  For years, Americans have avoided confronting these changes in their own backyards. The decisions made about where to live are distorted not just by politics that play down climate risks, but also by expensive subsidies and incentives aimed at defying nature. People have largely gravitated toward environmental danger, building along coastlines and settling across the cloudless deserts of the Southwest.  Once you accept that climate change is fast making large parts of the U.S. nearly uninhabitable, the future looks like this: With time, the bottom half of the country grows inhospitable, dangerous and hot. The millions of people moving north will mostly head to the cities of the Northeast and Northwest, which will see their populations grow by roughly 10%, according to one model.  To read more from this investigation published in @nytmag, tap the link in our bio. Photos by @meridithkohut.

Description: "Scientists believe our destructive relationship with nature is actually putting us at greater risk of pandemic diseases.”  David Attenborough looks at how the human impact on nature may be sparking more infectious diseases - from Ebola to Covid-19 - in his latest BBC special.  From our greater human exposure to wildlife through livestock markets, to animals losing their habitat due to deforestation and climate change, disease experts explore the warning signs facing humanity.  As the world continues to fight coronavirus, Attenborough says that if we continue on our current path "then what we've experienced this year might not be a one off event". UK viewers can watch ‘Extinction: The Facts’ presented by Sir David Attenborough on BBC iPlayer.  #Nature #AnimalsOfInstagram #DavidAttenborough #Extinction #Pandemic #Coronavirus #Covid19 #BBCIplayer #BBCNews
ImageText: (empty)

Description: The wildfires raging on the West Coast became an all but inescapable crisis around the country on Tuesday, with a death toll of at least 27 across 3 states, fires and evacuations starting in Idaho, milky smoke clouding the skies over Michigan, and haze reaching as far as New York City.  In the states where the fires are burning worst — Oregon, California and Washington State, which have had  more than 5 million acres charred so far — the authorities were trying to adapt to a disaster with no clear end in sight, under conditions deeply exacerbated by climate change.  The Bay Area, under a choking blanket of smoke for 4 weeks, set another record for consecutive warnings about hazardous air. The Oregon State Police established a mobile morgue as teams searched incinerated buildings for survivors and the dead. Alaska Airlines suspended flights out of Portland, Oregon, and Spokane, Washington, citing “thick smoke and haze.” And @oregongovbrown requested a presidential disaster declaration, saying late Monday, “to fight fires of this scale, we need all the help we can get.”  As the fires rage, climate change has taken center stage in the race for the White House. On Monday @joebiden called @realdonaldtrump a “climate arsonist” while the president said that “I don’t think science knows” what is actually happening.  Tap the links in our bio for the latest updates, a map of the fires and Trump’s visit to California. Photos by @alishajucevic, @ericthayer, @erinschaff and @nytmills
ImageText: (empty)

Description: In einem Dutzend amerikanischer Bundesstaaten zerstörten Waldbrände mittlerweile Millionen Hektar Land, mindestens 35 Menschen starben. Bilder vom roten Himmel im Katastrophengebiet sorgen auf der ganzen Welt für Entsetzen. Trotzdem dauerte es fast drei Wochen bis Präsident Donald Trump nach Kalifornien reiste, um sich ein Bild der Lage zu machen. Sein langes Schweigen rechtfertigte er damit, dass er zumindest den Notstand für die Gebiete erklärt habe, um Mittel freigeben zu können.  Im Gespräch mit kalifornischen Regierungsvertretern gab sich Trump dennoch weniger zurückhaltend. Wade Crowfoot, Chef des Amtes für Bodenschätze und natürliche Ressourcen, beschrieb dem Präsidenten die Situation im Bundesstaat. Die Temperaturen hätten in diesem Sommer alle Rekorde gebrochen; die Sommer würden in Zukunft noch wärmer werden, ebenso auch die Winter. Es sei wichtig zu verstehen, dass der Klimawandel für die Brände verantwortlich sei. Der Präsident reagierte spöttisch: „Es wird kühler werden, Sie werden schon sehen.“ Crowfoot entgegnete: „Ich wünschte, die Wissenschaft würde Ihnen Recht geben.“ Trump gab zurück: „Tatsächlich glaube ich nicht, dass die Wissenschaft das weiß.  Mehr zu der Situation finden Sie jetzt auf faz.net/insta (Link in Bio!).   #donaldtrump #kalifornien #amerika #usa
ImageText: (empty)

Description: President Trump has a head-scratching solution for the California wildfires: "It will start getting cooler."⁠ ⁠ Trump touched down in California on Monday to survey the wildfire damage and immediately launched into his usual talking points about poor forest management while denying the role of climate change. ⁠ ⁠ Trump arrived in Sacramento as more than two dozen major wildfires burned across the state. More than 2 million acres in the state have burned this year, a nearly 2,000% increase in land burned compared to this time last year.⁠ ⁠ At a roundtable discussion about the wildfires, California Secretary for Natural Resources Wade Crowfoot said Trump’s focus on forest management was obscuring the grim reality that climate change was behind the historically high temperatures and years of drought.⁠ ⁠ “It will start getting cooler. You just watch,” Trump fired back at Crowfoot.⁠ ⁠ "I wish science agreed with you," Crowfoot replied.⁠ ⁠ “I don’t think science knows actually,” Trump concluded. Read more at our link in bio.
ImageText: FIRE VAS SERVIC RES It'll start getting cooler.

Description: President Trump says forest management is a primary culprit for Western wildfires and not climate change, as California officials and scientists say.⁠ ⁠
ImageText: USA TODAY President Trump said mismanagement of forestland is a primary culprit for raging Western wildfires

Description: Five cyclones are swirling around the Atlantic Ocean at the same time. As far as our records go, this has only ever happened once before in 1971.⁠ ⁠ Out of storms Paulette, Rene, Sally, Teddy and Vicky, two have strengthened into hurricanes as they head towards the US.⁠ ⁠ People were ordered to evacuate on Monday as Hurricane Sally hurtled across the Gulf of Mexico towards Louisiana and Mississippi. The storm is expected to bring "extreme life-threatening" flash flooding, storm surge and strong winds when it hits later today, according to the US National Hurricane Center.⁠ ⁠ It's the second major storm to hit the region within a month, following Hurricane Laura in August which killed dozens of people in the US and the Caribbean and caused widespread devastation.⁠ ⁠ Hurricane Paulette made rare landfall in Bermuda on Monday night. The island has been hit directly by fewer than 10 hurricanes since records began in the 1850s. No deaths, injuries or serious damage were reported.⁠ ⁠ There have been 20 hurricanes in the Atlantic storm season so far this year - so many that forecasters are running out of names for them. Once all the names on the list are used up, further storms will be named after letters of the Greek alphabet.⁠ ⁠ Scientists say the climate crisis and rising global temperatures are increasing the intensity of cyclones and affecting where in the world they form.⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ #hurricane #cyclone #extremeweather #hurricanesally #hurricanepaulette #climatecrisis #climatechange #climateemergency #storm #floods #louisiana #mississippi #bermuda
ImageText: There are five tropical cyclones raging in the Atlantio Ocean at the same time. It's only the second time it's happened on record. @channel4news

Description: The #Bobcatfire has managed to outwit firefighters, even in the absence of powerful Santa Ana winds that failed to materialize as predicted last week. Instead, officials say, the Bobcat fire’s power lies in two factors: its location and an inadequate supply of firefighters. But climate experts warn there are larger factors at play.  “This fire was man-made on many levels,” said Bill Patzert, a climatologist who spent several decades at the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory in La Cañada Flintridge. Record heat, population growth, fossil fuels and other factors related to climate change have contributed not only to the state’s unprecedented fire season, Patzert said, but also to the particular challenges of the Bobcat fire. Read more at the link in our bio. 📸: David McNew / @gettyimages

Description: "It'll start getting cooler, you just watch... I don't think science knows actually."  President Trump has dismissed concerns over climate change on a visit to fire-ravaged California. Blazes in Oregon, California and Washington state have burned almost 2m hectares (5m acres) of land and killed at least 36 people since early August. During his visit to the US West Coast, Mr Trump repeated his argument that poor forest management was to blame as he met officials involved in the battle against the wildfires. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the story.  #Oregon #California #fires #wildfires #Trump #climate #climatechange #bbcnews

Description: Die Waldbrände an der Westküste der USA sorgen auch für politischen Streit: Auf der einen Seite die Demokraten, die die Ursache der Brände im Voranschreiten des Klimawandels sehen, und US-Präsident Trump auf der anderen Seite glaubt, die betroffenen Bundesstaaten seien an den verheerenden Bränden selbst schuld. Man halte dort nämlich die Wälder nicht richtig instand.  Wald-Experte Peter Wohlleben sagt dazu: „Wenn ich Wälder ramponiere, ausräume, heizt sich das Lokalklima auf – unabhängig vom Klimawandel. Es wird trockener. Wenn dann der Klimawandel noch dazu kommt, findet das Feuer natürlich ganz leicht Nahrung in diesen ausgetrockneten ehemaligen intakten Ökosystemen.“  Peter Wohlleben ist unter anderem Buch durch sein Buch "Das geheime Leben der Bäume" bekannt geworden. Auch im Deutschlandfunk setzt er sich für eine ökologische Waldwirtschaft ein: „Diese ramponierten Wälder - durch Holzeinschlag, durch Rodungen der vergangenen Jahrhunderte, das ist kein neues Phänomen - sind so klein und zerstückelt und mit geringer Biomasse ausgestattet, dass die nicht mehr richtig funktionieren in Bezug auf die Wasserkreisläufe.“  Das ganze Interview finden Sie über den Link in unserer Bio ⬆️  #wald #waldbrand #brand #feuer #waldsterben #baum #bäume #nature #natur #klimawandel #kalifornien #usa #amerika #instapolitics @peter_wohlleben

The impact of climate change is being felt in the Pacific island nation of Fiji, where coastal erosion, rising sea levels and intense cyclones have forced people to leave their homes. Villages near the sea are becoming abandoned as residents move inland to higher ground.  #Fiji #flooding #climate #climatechange #bbcnews

Description: “If you give a climate arsonist four more years in the White House, why would anyone be surprised if we have more of American ablaze,” Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden said Monday. ⁠ ⁠ Urgent action is needed, he said, to prevent climate change, pointing to worsening Western wildfires that have killed dozens of people and scorched 5 million acres across 10 states this year. ⁠ ⁠ Biden, a former vice president, said in a speech outside the Delaware Museum of Natural History in Wilmington that he would rejoin the Paris climate agreement to reduce greenhouse emissions. President Donald Trump withdrew from the agreement, saying other countries got unfair advantage from it.⁠ ⁠ Biden also said that he would spur the development of renewable energy through steps such as shifting the federal fleet of vehicles from fossil fuels to electric power. But Biden said the country wouldn't be safe with Trump, who has called climate change a "hoax."⁠ ⁠ 👉 Read more at our link in bio. ⁠ ⁠ #climatechange #wildfires #joebiden #donaldtrump
ImageText: Text UNITED o30330 BIDEN HARRIS We need a president who respects science, who understands that the damage from climate change is already here and unless we take urgent action, it'll soon be more catastrophic. Joe Biden Democratic nominee for president USA TODAY

Description: Joe Biden delivered a speech about the climate crisis and said Americans “aren’t safe” after President Trump’s failure to address it:  “If you give a climate arsonist four more years in the White House, why would anyone be surprised if we have more of America ablaze? If you give a climate denier four more years in the White House, why would anyone be surprised when more of America is underwater?”

Description: Las imágenes California envuelta en llamas han vuelto a poner de manifiesto el debate sobre el cambio climático. El gobernador del estado, Gavin Newsom, considera que no hay disputa posible sobre este tema: "Véanlo con sus propios ojos. Ni siquiera es un debate. Es una maldita emergencia climática".   Así de contundente se ha mostrado el gobernador, que recibirá la visita del presidente, Donald Trump, esta semana. Las críticas contra Trump se han sucedido después de que prácticamente no hiciera mención a los incendios en los últimos días. Estos incendios forestales son ya los segundos más graves de toda la historia del estado, y han dejado imágenes preocupantes, como la ciudad de San Francisco teñida de naranja en plena mañana debido a las partículas en suspensión procedentes de los incendios.  #crisisclimatica #climatecrisis #california #incendios #incendiosforestales #fire #californiafires #videooftheday

Description: A big chunk of ice has broken away from the Arctic's largest remaining ice shelf - 79N, or Nioghalvfjerdsfjorden - in north-east Greenland. The section covers about 110 square km and satellite imagery shows that it’s shattered into many small pieces. The loss is further evidence of the rapid climate change taking place in Greenland, scientist say. "The atmosphere in this region has warmed by about 3C since 1980," said Dr Jenny Turton. "And in 2019 and 2020, it saw record summer temperatures," the polar researcher at Friedrich-Alexander University in Germany told BBC News. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the shattered ice and the impact a warming climate is having. (Copernicus Data/ESA/Sentinel-2b) #ClimateChange #Environment #Greenland #Satellite #bbcnews

Description: Much of our Sunday print edition focuses on the climate change-fueled moment Californians are living through right now. Here's a look at some of the featured pieces:  • Reporters Susanne Rust and Tony Barboza break down how the extreme #wildfires, heat and smog California has experienced in recent weeks were all made worse by #climatechange.  • Columnist Steve Lopez asks, "Is the #California we knew and loved up in smoke for good?" (It isn't. But we all need to change, Lopez writes.)  • Columnist Erika D. Smith wants to know if you're as confused as she is about all of these “complex” fires? She reports how in normal times, fires were named after landmarks. But these are abnormal times.  • Culture columnist and critic Mary McNamara reflects on life in California and how this moment shows how the state's residents are tough — much tougher than you may think.  • Metro reporter and Essential California newsletter author Julia Wick explains how there's actually a word for the climate change-induced despair you may be feeling and traces its origin.  Read all of these pieces and more of our environment coverage at the link in our bio.

Description: “El debate sobre el cambio climático ha terminado. Simplemente, vengan a California. Véanlo con sus propios ojos. No es un debate intelectual. Ni siquiera es un debate. Es una maldita emergencia climática. Esto es real”. El gobernador de California, Gavin Newsom, visitó el viernes una de las zonas quemadas de Sacramento y después dio este corto discurso. “No tengo ninguna paciencia con los negacionistas del cambio climático”, había dicho unos días antes. Los incendios están arrasando la costa oeste de EE UU y los bomberos buscan cadáveres entre las cenizas en Oregón y California. Las imágenes de satélite muestran los 2.000 kilómetros de costa cubiertos de humo

Description: Democratic California Gov. Gavin Newsom is blaming climate change for deadly wildfires to distract from the fact that his party's policies created the conditions for such blazes in the first places, Republican Assemblyman James Gallagher told "Tucker Carlson Tonight" Friday.⁣ ⁣ "The Democrats who control this state, have been in charge of the legislature, and hold every statewide office have failed to take care of forestry management in California," Gallagher told host Tucker Carlson. "We have overgrown forests with brush piles ten feet high and dead and dying trees and it's a tinderbox waiting for a spark."⁣ ⁣ Go to the link in our bio for more on this story.

Description: Im Kampf gegen den globalen Klimawandel geht es vorrangig darum, den Ausstoß an Kohlendioxid zu reduzieren. Doch das alleine dürfte nicht ausreichen. Um die Schutzziele aus dem Pariser Vertrag einhalten zu können, muss eine gewisse Menge des Treibhausgases der Atmosphäre auch wieder dauerhaft entzogen werden. Negative Emissionen nennt man das. Einfach und schnell ließe sich das verwirklichen, indem man große Flächen mit Wald aufforstet – dachte man bisher. Aber jetzt zeigt eine Studie aus Nature Communications, dass die Rechnung doch etwas komplizierter sein dürfte. . . . Den Link zum Beitrag finden Sie in unserer Bio. . . . #klima #klimawandel #co2 #carbon #kohlendioxid #wald #baum #dlf #deutschlandfunk

Description: Wildfires are common in California, but as the state has heated up, they have burned further, for longer.⁠ ⁠ Parts of the sunshine state have warmed 2C in the past century, compared to the global average of 1C, and earlier this year its Death Valley had the highest global temperature on record, reaching 54.4C. ⁠ ⁠ The link between wildfires and climate change is simple, though quantifying it is harder: hotter air means more areas of drier vegetation, which act as a tinderbox.⁠ ⁠ The ten largest California fires since 1932 have all occurred since 2000 and this year’s have already hit a new record, having arrived much earlier than usual.⁠ ⁠ Read more via the link in bio⁠ ⁠ #Californiawildfires #SanFrancisco #climatechange #naturaldisaster #California #firefighters ⁠

"We need the federal government to partner with California and other states on the procurement and buildout of clean energy infrastructure, to include more solar and wind farms and the construction of high-efficiency batteries to store increased capacity." Read her op-ed at the link in our bio. 📸: @pixtakerirfan

Description: Oregon is experiencing its worst fires in memory, with at least three deaths and swaths of two small cities burned to the ground. Hundreds of homes and other structures have been destroyed. Skies have turned bright orange or dark gray across the western part of the state, which is experiencing some of the worst air quality ever recorded.  Scientists say roaring winds were the equivalent of the notorious Santa Anas of Southern California. Their rare appearance in the rainforests of the Pacific Northwest is almost certainly due to climate change, according to researchers. And like the winds that race down the mountainsides near #LosAngeles each fall, gaining heat and fanning the flames as they go, the gales that struck #Oregon over the weekend have turned small #fires into infernos. More in our bio. 📸: Kathryn Elsesser / AFP - @gettyimages
ImageText: Climate change brings Santa Ana-like winds and explosive wildfires to Oregon

Description: As deadly wildfires continue to devastate America's north-west, Washington governor Jay Inslee has blamed abnormally dry conditions and high temperatures fuelled by climate change for making the fires "so explosive."  Fires in Oregon have turned the sky blood orange red and forced hundreds of thousands of people to flee their homes. In Washington state, 600,000 acres have burned while hot, dry weather conditions in northern California have made the spread of multiple blazes easier.  The wildfires are estimated to be six times greater than they were at this time last year.  Inslee, who ran for the Democratic presidential nomination on a ticket that put the climate crisis as the number one issue facing America and the world, has now urged a rethink about how the wildfires are reported on.
ImageText: G We talk about this as wildfires, but we have to start thinking about it as more of a climate fire. Jay Inslee, Washington governor

Description: The world's wildlife populations have fallen by an average of 68% in just over four decades, with human consumption behind the devastating decline, the World Wildlife Fund warned in a new report. Latin America and the Caribbean are the world's worst-affected areas, with an average drop of 94%, the report said. Experts say that while the climate crisis is not yet the biggest cause of biodiversity loss, in the coming years, the climate crisis will become a key driver of species decline unless world leaders take action.⁠ (📸: Getty Images)⁠
ImageText: CNN Human activity has wiped out two-thirds of world's wildlife since 1970, report says The report says that the kinds of steep wildlife populatior decreases the Earth has seen in recent decades have not been seen for millions of years

Description: Lung-damaging ozone #pollution in L.A. reached its highest levels in a generation and set records in other parts of Southern California during the blistering Labor Day weekend heat wave, air quality readings show.  Ozone pollution spiked to 185 parts per billion in downtown L.A. at midday Sunday, according to South Coast Air Quality Management District monitoring data. It was the highest hourly reading in Southern California since 2003 and the highest in downtown L.A. in 26 years.  Air quality officials said the high pollution readings were a result of intense heat combined with stagnant weather conditions and winds that were too weak to sweep away much pollution.   In the big picture, climate change is an underlying cause, according to air quality experts. Scientific studies have found that rising temperatures are making smog harder to control by speeding up the photochemical reactions that generate ozone gas.  Link in bio. 📸: Allen J. Schaben/ Los Angeles Times
ImageText: (empty)

Description: It’s been another hellacious week in #California. Extraordinary heat. Out-of-control #fires. Dangerous rescues. A faltering power grid. Ash falling from darkened, orange skies. All of it influenced by the invisible hand of climate change, by way of the greenhouse gases we pump into the atmosphere when we fill our cars with oil, burn coal and natural gas for electricity, and chop down forests.  Even knowing how polarized American politics have become, it’s hard to imagine two candidates as diametrically opposed on any issue as Joe Biden and Donald Trump are on climate change. Description: More than one hundred regular members of the public have come together to hear from experts and give recommendations on how the government should tackle the climate crisis.⁠ ⁠ The UK has a legally binding target to reach net zero carbon emissions by 2050 - a transition which will require such huge changes that MPs instigated the Climate Assembly UK to give a representative sample of the UK population a say in how it happens.⁠ ⁠ The results of 60 hours worth of meetings over six months are published today. The recommendations, including on specific policy as well as overarching principles, are being sent to the Prime Minister, with responses from both government and MPs expected in the coming months.⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ #climateassembly #climatepolicy #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency #transport #agriculture #renewables
ImageText: Members of of the public have given the UK government their ideas ideas on how to tackle climate change. Here's what they said. @channel4news

Description: Wildfires are worsening — but the way we manage them isn’t keeping pace.⁣ ⁣ In the U.S., wildfires are ravaging the West. In California alone, 5 of the largest blazes on record have all struck in just the past 4 years, serving as a deadly reminder that the nation is far behind in adopting policies widely known to protect lives and property, even though worsening fires have become a predictable consequence of climate change.⁣ ⁣ Colorado, Washington and Oregon are facing record fire seasons. And California, with 2.5 million acres burned so far, has 14,000 firefighters working to contain 25 major wildfires even though “this year’s fire season has another four months to go,” according to @calfire.⁣ ⁣ The worsening wildfire disasters mean the U.S. needs to drastically rethink its approach to managing fire in the decades ahead, experts warn. “The first step is to acknowledge that fire is inevitable, and we have to learn to live with it,” said David McWethy, a fire scientist at @montanastateuniversity.⁣ ⁣ A century of federal policy to aggressively extinguish all wildfires rather than letting some burn at low levels, an approach now seen as misguided, has left forests with plenty of fuel for especially destructive blazes. This is all in an era when global warming is creating a hotter, drier environment, loading the dice for more extensive fires.⁣ ⁣ Some cities and states have taken important steps, such as imposing tougher regulations on homes built in fire-prone areas. And there has been movement toward using prescribed fires to scour away excess vegetation that can fuel runaway blazes in forests and grasslands.⁣ ⁣ But these changes are still happening too slowly, experts say, and have been overtaken by the rapid increase in wildfires.⁣ ⁣ Tap the link in our bio to see the latest from the wildfires and to read more about the changes experts say are needed amid worsening fires. Photos by @maxwhittaker from the North Complex Fire in California. ⁣
ImageText: (empty)

Description: The San Francisco Bay Area awoke to a disorienting sight on Wednesday morning: deep orange skies and a smoky darkness lingered hours after sunrise, serving as a stark reminder of the wildfires still raging across California.⁠⠀ ⁠⠀ The phenomenon ― which was also seen in Oregon on Tuesday ― is a result of 16 different fire complexes burning in the region, dispersing smoke with the help of gusty wind. ⁠⠀ ⁠⠀ “Strong winds over the past few days transported ash from fires in northern California and the Sierra Nevada into the region,” the Bay Area Air District, the region’s air quality control agency, explained in a tweet.⁠⠀ ⁠⠀ “If smoke becomes too thick in a certain area, most of the light will be scattered & absorbed before reaching the surface, which may cause dark skies.” A thick layer of marine fog below the smoky skies aided the effect. ⁠⠀ ⁠⠀ The National Weather Service’s Bay Area branch warned that even though the air quality in the region was moderate on Wednesday morning, the “unprecedented smoke” hanging high in the air will likely descend closer to street level as the day goes on, making the air more dangerous to breathe.⁠⠀ ⁠⠀ It’s a familiar warning for Californians. Uncontrolled blazes across the state this year have so far burned a historic 2.3 million acres, representing a nearly 2,000% increase in land burned compared with this time last year, according to the California Department of Forestry and Fire Protection.⁠⠀ ⁠⠀ “This is yet another reminder though that we’re living with the effects of climate change in real time,” San Francisco Mayor London Breed tweeted Wednesday morning. ⁠⠀ ⁠⠀ Here are some images of Wednesday’s orange skies, which many compared to a scene from Mars. // 📷 The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

Description: 500 glaciares desaparecen en los últimos 40 años • La misma foto más de 100 años después y no hay color. El glaciar Trient, en Suiza, prácticamente ha desaparecido. Por ello más de 200 personas caminaron hasta su pie en el macizo Mont Blanc para concienciar sobre el impacto del cambio climático en el paisaje helvético. Ha perdido mil metros en los útlimos 30 años, denuncian los activistas, que avisan de que el aumento de más de 2 grados de la temperatura hace que los glaciares se estén derritiendo. Han saltado las alarmas porque en menos de cuatro décadas 500 glaciares han desaparecido ya o están a punto de hacerlo. La Asociación Suiza para la Protección del Clima llama a actuar ahora para no perder estas importantes fuentes de agua dulce antes de finales de siglo.  #Glaciar #Naturaleza #Deshielo #CambioClimático

Description: A project to create a wall of vegetation in Africa three times the size of Australia's Great Barrier Reef is not currently on track to be delivered by its target date in 2030, according to a UN report.   The Great Green Wall is a planned 100-million-hectare area of trees and plants stretching from Senegal to Djibouti to hold back the spread of desert into fertile land. Desertification is being sped up by climate change, reducing the amount of land suitable for grazing livestock and growing crops and affecting around 1.5 billion people globally, according to the UN.   A status report published yesterday examined the progress 11 countries in the Sahel had made since the project began in 2007. The Sahel is one of the regions most severely affected by drought and deterioration of soil quality and vegetation cover.  Although participating countries have restored around 18 million hectares of land, just 4 million hectares were planted within the Great Green Wall target area. To hit the 2030 deadline, more than twice that area will need to be restored every year at a cost of $4.3 billion annually.   Ethiopia has restored the biggest area so far, with 5.5 billion plants and seedlings produced. Other countries have been slower to make progress due to differences in geography, governance and economic development.  The report authors say more funding and technical support along with better governance and monitoring are needed for the project to be successful. . . . . . . . #reforestation #desertification #climatechange #climatecrisis #climateemergency #drought #trees #plants #africa

Description: Animal Rebellion group have delivered a letter to Downing Street, accusing the government of “failing to address the cause” of the coronavirus pandemic.   The animal rights and climate activist group, which is an offshoot of Extinction Rebellion, want the government to lead a transition to a plant-based food system, saying it will “reduce the risk of future pandemics”.   Extinction Rebellion has been staging a number of protests after they were put on hold due to the coronavirus pandemic.   Hundreds of the demonstrators have been arrested during the climate crisis protests, which included blocking access to two print works and gluing themselves to the street outside parliament.  #animalrebellion #extinctionrebellion #climatechange #protests #pandemic #covid19 #coronavirus

Description: Los incendios de California nos muestran el Armagedón climático.  Ningún guionista de Hollywood podría haber imaginado una imagen más apocalíptica que la de los potentes helicópteros de combate del ejército estadounidense evacuando a los más de doscientos ciudadanos rescatados de la línea de fuego y que, apiñados en el interior de las aeronaves, con la ropa chamuscada y la mirada perdida, eran la viva imagen del espanto.   El estado más poblado y rico de Estados Unidos sufre la peor oleada de incendios de su historia y su gobernador apunta que ahora el peor enemigo es el cambio climático.   Gavin Newson amplió la declaración del estado de emergencia este domingo en mitad del espectacular dispositivo de rescate organizado por la Guardia Nacional una vez que los medios de extinción se veían superados por la virulencia y la velocidad de propagación de las llamas.  Más información en el link de la bio 📲 https://bit.ly/2Fjjazq ✍️ José Luis Gallego #incendios #california #crisisclimatica #cambioclimatico

Description: New satellite images show the full extent of the devastating damage caused by the recent Australian wildfires.⁠ ⁠ Last year hundreds of fires burnt through an estimated 5.5 million hectares in New South Wales (NSW) during what's now been dubbed the 'Black Summer'. It killed at least 33 people, destroyed thousands of homes and affected billions of animals. ⁠ ⁠ The NSW government commissioned aerial analysis company Geospatial Intelligence to capture images both before and after the 2019 fire season. The images provide useful monitoring information about the landscape that could help with future bushfire recovery and mitigation activities.⁠ ⁠ The final report from an inquiry into the bushfires published at the end of July found Australia should expect even worse fire seasons in years to come as climate change intensifies. ⁠ ⁠ Image credit: Geospatial Intelligence Pty Ltd⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ #wildfires #australia #newsouthwales #bushfires #satellite #climatechange #climateeemergency #climatecrisis
ImageText: (empty)

Description: @elmostrador_cultura Un grupo de científicos y expertos elaboró el primer análisis exhaustivo a nivel global sobre cuáles son las áreas terrestres esenciales para la biodiversidad y la resiliencia climática, y cuya conclusión es que estas representan el 50,4% de la superficie del planeta. El reporte se publicó ayer en la revista Science Advances y se tituló: “La ‘Red de Protección Global’ para revertir la pérdida de la biodiversidad y estabilizar el clima de la Tierra” (1). El reporte destaca la importancia de salvaguardar y restaurar el mundo natural para poder abordar tres crisis convergentes: el cambio climático, la pérdida de biodiversidad y la aparición de nuevos virus, como el COVID 19.  El equipo de especialistas estuvo liderado por la organización de investigación científica RESOLVE, en colaboración con la Universidad de Minesota, la Universidad Estatal de Arizona, Globaïa y otras más, con el apoyo de One Earth. Los datos compilados para la Red de Protección Global - Global Safety Net (GSN1) están disponibles a través de una aplicación web interactiva y desarrollada por One Earth en asociación con Google Earth Engine. Los usuarios pueden dar clic sobre un país, estado o ecorregión para conocer la conformación de las zonas de importancia biológica para cada una de las regiones.  👉continúa leyendo en el link de la bio❗️ #ciencia #clima #chile
ImageText: CULTURA CIENCIA Científicos lanzan esquema para salvar los ecosistemas críticos y estabilizar el clima del mundo por Héctor Cossio López 7 septiembre, 2020

Description: Después de varias décadas, Galicia recupera a sus ballenas. Esta semana, un velero de la armada se topaba con un grupo de orcas en rías baixas. Los expertos investigan lo sucedido y no tienen claras las causas. Según Alfredo López, biólogo marino de Cemma: "no es frecuente que un animal tenga contacto físico con un barco y menos que tenga daños". Para evitar que el timón quede malparado, lo recomendable es rebajar siempre la velocidad. Según López: "ellos son competitivos y si ven aceleración van a nadar siempre más rápido". Esta semana en Galicia también se han avistado ballenas azules de veinte metros. Y hasta rorcuales. Vienen porque hay exceso de krill, los moluscos que tanto gustan a estos animales. Pero hay más razones. Según López: "por el calentamiento global ya no bajan tanto y quedan aquí". Prefieren el frío de las aguas gallegas.    #Galicia #Ballenas
ImageText: (empty)

Description: @elmostrador_cultura Continúa el Ciclo de Entrevistas Pioneros del Cambio de Fundación Hypatia. El cuarto conversatorio online se titula “Diálogo y Transformación de Conflictos” y contará con la presencia de Alfredo Zamudio, director ejecutivo del Centro Nansen para la Paz y el Diálogo y destacado facilitador de procesos de diálogo a nivel global, con más de 30 años de experiencia en gestión de derechos humanos, emergencias humanitarias y transformación de conflictos. Originario de Arica, Zamudio ha vivido en Noruega desde 1976, ha sido director de la Casa de Derechos Humanos de Oslo, director del Centro de Monitoreo del Desplazamiento Interno en Ginebra y consejero del Alto Comisionado de Naciones Unidas para los Refugiados.  En las últimas décadas ha contribuido a la construcción de la paz en lugares como Colombia, Sudán, Timor Oriental, entre otros. Desde el 2019, Alfredo Zamudio ha dado charlas en nuestro país y con el equipo Nansen en Chile, han apoyado capacidades de diálogo. Esta quinta versión del Ciclo de Entrevistas de Fundación Hypatia está co-organizada y patrocinada por el Centro Cultural de España –CCE-Santiago– y realizada en alianza con El Mostrador. Las invitadas e invitados al ciclo son agentes de cambio relevantes de Chile y el mundo en temas de desarrollo humano, ética, cambio climático, regeneración, equidad de género, paz, diálogo y cuidado medioambiental.  La periodista Aleka Vial, directora de Fundación Hypatia, facilita las conversaciones del ciclo en el que ya han participado los filósofos Gastón Soublette y Ziley Mora; la climatóloga Maisa Rojas, el investigador en regeneración Ronald Sistek, la presidenta de Comunidad Mujer, Mercedes Ducci y la directora ejecutiva de Hay Mujeres, Mai-Nié Chang.
ImageText: CULTURA Alfredo Zamudio en Ciclo de Entrevistas Pioneros del Cambio Cambio de Fundación Hypatia por El Mostrador Cultura 6 septiembre, 2020

Description: "Als ich 14 Jahre alt war, erzählte mir meine Freundin Maria auf den Philippinen, dass sie ein Schulfach nicht bestanden hat, weil sie nachts nicht lernen kann – der Strom war zu teuer für ihre Familie. Ich bin selbst Halbphilippinerin, wir waren dort, um die Familie zu besuchen.   Marias Problem hat mich auf die Idee gebracht, mein Wissenschaftsprojekt an der Schule diesem Thema zu widmen und eine Taschenlampe zu erfinden, die keine Batterien und keinen Strom braucht." Description: As the second major #heatwave in weeks bears down on Southern California, experts and authorities are warning the public to take seriously the health dangers of extreme temperatures that are only getting worse due to #climatechange.    “Heat of this magnitude is rare, dangerous and very possibly deadly,” the National Weather Service warned.    #Wildfires, elevated #smog levels and possible power outages may pose additional threats. The #pandemic, meanwhile, could make this #LaborDay weekend especially deadly, as #coronavirus restrictions have closed many of the cooled indoor spaces that usually offer relief.    Exacerbating it all is climate change, which researchers say is increasing the frequency and intensity of extreme heat events. As greenhouse gases continue to rise globally, heat spells of this severity are an unfortunate reality that Californians will increasingly have to get used to, they say. Visit the link in our bio to read more. 📸: @luissinco
ImageText: As second heat wave sears California, experts say health impacts will worsen with climate change

Description: 72 people have been arrested after trying to prevent a number of national newspapers from reaching people this morning.⁠ ⁠ Over 100 Extinction Rebellion protesters used bamboo structures and trucks to block roads outside printworks in Broxbourne, Hertfordshire, and Knowsley near Liverpool.⁠ ⁠ The group has accused some of the papers for failing to report on climate change.⁠ ⁠ They said: “The right-wing media is a barrier to the truth, failing to reflect the scale and urgency of the crisis and hold governments to account.⁠ ⁠ “Coverage in many of the newspapers printed here is polluting national debate on climate change, immigration policy, the rights and treatment of minority groups, and on dozens of other issues.”⁠ ⁠ Five major national newspapers including the Sun, the Times and the Daily Mail were affected.⁠ ⁠ Boris Johnson condemned the protest group's actions in a Tweet, stating: "A free press is vital in holding the government and other powerful institutions to account on issues critical for the future of our country, including the fight against climate change.⁠ ⁠ "It is completely unacceptable to seek to limit the public’s access to news in this way.⁠" ⁠ The Sun has refuted Extinction Rebellion’s claims - tweeting a climate change piece by Sir David Attenborough that featured their paper today.⁠  📷 Extinction Rebellion .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ .⁠ #climate #climatecrisis #climateemergency #climatechange #environment #nature #globalwarming #sustainability #earth #extinctionrebellion #protest #protesters #media #newspapers  #climateaction #hertfordshire #merseyside #davidattenborough

Description: A seis meses de iniciada la pandemia en Chile, pareciera que todo puede cambiar. Dicen que se apretó el acelerador, reduciendo a solo algunos meses aquel tiempo de las transformaciones que para muchos iban a tomar 10 años. Lo que antes parecía imposible, hoy es una necesidad para afrontar la realidad. Y los cambios acelerados traen incertidumbre, una sensación que no para de repetirse dentro de las consultas ciudadanas que desarrollamos desde la plataforma "Tenemos que Hablar de Chile", iniciativa impulsada desde las universidades Católica y de Chile, junto a otras varias organizaciones, que ya cuenta con las opiniones, anhelos e ideas de más de 40.000 personas a lo largo de todo el país. ¿Cómo saldremos de todo esto? ¿Qué va a pasar con nuestras vidas? Son preguntas que no tienen respuestas certeras, pero que sí rondan nuestras reflexiones diarias, especialmente en las de aquellas personas que viven situaciones de mayor dificultad y precariedad. La historia se está escribiendo saltando de crisis en crisis, desde el calentamiento global, pasando por la crisis sanitaria, la social y la económica. La sensación de incertidumbre va a marcar el comienzo de una nueva década y, quizás, de una nueva era tanto para el mundo como para Chile. 👉continúa leyendo en el link de la bio❗️
ImageText: OPINIÓN Convivir en la incertidumbre por Hernán Hochschild 5 de septiembre de 2020

Description: "Im Februar sank der Wasserstand am Kariba-Staudamm, dem wichtigsten Wasserkraftwerk des Landes, auf ein Rekordtief, es produzierte immer weniger Strom. Die Leute begannen, Brennholz zum Kochen zu verwenden, mussten also Bäume fällen – auch in Marondera.  Das in meinem direkten Umfeld zu erleben, hat mich umdenken lassen. Ich habe das Unternehmen 'Everlasting Technology' gegründet, mit dem Ziel, die Rodung und Abholzung zu stoppen und Innovationen im Bereich der erneuerbaren Energien anzubieten: Wir entwickeln tragbare Biogasanlagen, die organische Abfälle nutzen, um Biogas und Strom zu produzieren." Description: La Carta Magna de 1980 estableció el derecho a un medioambiente sin contaminación, pero en el mundo académico y jurista concuerdan que esa contribución está superada. Cuarenta años después, el escenario no es el mismo debido a problemas como la crisis climática, la degradación de la biodiversidad y la escasez del agua. Para los expertos, una nueva hoja de ruta debiera incorporar ciertas urgencias de la sociedad, como la reducción de emisiones y el legado de un planeta sano para las futuras generaciones.  Todo el detalle deslizando nuestras historias.

Description: "Mit 15 habe ich ein System entwickelt, das allein durch Solarenergie aus Regenwasser Trinkwasser macht und in entlegenen und isolierten Regionen angewendet werden kann. Normalerweise wird das Wasser dort mit Chlor versetzt oder abgekocht, wofür man wiederum Gas oder Feuerholz braucht.  Durch meine Aufbereitungsanlage können die Menschen dort nicht nur auf Chemikalien verzichten und Ressourcen und CO₂ sparen. Sondern sie haben auch einen unabhängigen Zugang zu sauberem Wasser und somit ein geringeres Risiko, Krankheiten zu bekommen." Description: El mar de Bering sufre el mayor deshielo de los últimos (por lo menos) 5.500 años.   El mar de Bering, porción del océano Pacífico entre Alaska y Siberia, no se escapa al deshielo que afecta la mayor parte de la región ártica. Un nuevo estudio internacional publicado este mes de setiembre en la revista Science Advances indica que en los inviernos de 2018 y 2019 se registró en la isla San Mateo (Alaska, EE.UU.), en la zona central del mar de Bering, el nivel más bajo de hielo marino (flotante) en los últimos 5.500 años (periodo estudiado, no se descarta que el récord afecte a muchos más años atrás).  El equipo de este estudio analiza la alta sensibilidad de los hielos de esta zona ártica a las variaciones de concentración de dióxido de carbono en la atmósfera, uno de los procesos que actualmente está provocando el cambio climático.  Los datos de los satélites ofrecen una clara imagen de cómo ha cambiado el hielo marino en las últimas cuatro décadas en la región entre el Ártico y el norte del océano Pacífico. Más allá, los únicos registros de hielo disponibles son los de barcos y otras observaciones.  ✍️ Joaquim Elcacho 📸 Mark Ralston  Toda la información en el link de nuestra bio 📲 https://bit.ly/2DpqMzA  #mardebering #cambioclimatico #deshielo

Description: Extinction Rebellion (XR) activists are into a third day of demonstrations in London.  A 10-day series of "mass rebellions" started outside the Houses of Parliament on 1 September with gatherings planned across the UK during that time. Nearly 300 people have been arrested since the start of protests in the capital. Some XR supporters staged a sit-in while others, calling themselves Animal Rebellion, locked themselves on top of a pink slaughterhouse truck parked sideways across a road in central London. The campaigners said they are demanding "a plant-based food system as a means to mitigate the worst impacts of the climate crisis and reduce the risk of future pandemics". (Getty Images) #Protests #ClimateChange #BBCNews
